message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: A Survey of Autonomous Underwater Vehicle Formation: Performance, Formation Control, and Communication Capability
Paper Abstract: Autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) are submersible underwater vehicles controlled by onboard computers. AUV formation is a cooperative control which focuses on controlling multiple AUVs to move in a group while executing tasks. In contrast to a single AUV, multi-AUV formation represents higher efficiency and better stability for many applications, such as oil and gas industries, hydrographic surveys, and military missions, etc. To achieve better formation, there are several key factors, including AUV performance, formation control, and communication capability. However, most studies in the field of AUV formation mainly focus on formation control methods. We observe that the research of communication capability and AUV performance of multiple AUV formation is still in an early stage. It is beneficial to researchers to present a comprehensive survey of the state of the art of AUV formation research and development. In this paper, we study AUV, formation control, and underwater acoustic communication capability in detail. We propose a classification framework with three dimensions, including AUV performance, formation control, and communication capability. This framework provides a comprehensive classification method for future AUV formation research. It also can be used to compare different methods and help engineers choose suitable formation methods for various applications. Moreover, our survey discusses formation architecture with communication constraints and we identify some common misconceptions and questionable research for formation control related to communication.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Talk:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Template:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_planning"}]

## Multi-Agent System

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

### Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system have important characteristics including autonomy (agents are at least partially independent and self-aware) and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).(no content)Multi-agent systems can manifest self-organisation and self-direction even when the individual strategies of all their agents are simple.

### Composition and Types of Agents

While multi-agent systems research typically refers to software agents, the agents could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)Agents can be divided into types spanning simple to complex.

### Recent Developments

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

### Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

Links: [{"title":"Cooperative multitasking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_multitasking"},{"title":"Cooperative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative"},{"title":"Collaborative Control Theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_Control_Theory"},{"title":"Worker cooperative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Worker_cooperative"},{"title":"Communication, navigation and surveillance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication,_navigation_and_surveillance"},{"title":"Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_Adaptive_Cruise_Control"},{"title":"Consumer cooperative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_cooperative"},{"title":"Workers' control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workers'_control"},{"title":"Consumers' co-operative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumers'_co-operative"},{"title":"Rochdale Principles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_principles"}]

Based on the search results, here are several different interpretations of "Cooperative control" depending on the context:

## General Business/Organization Context

Cooperative control refers to member-controlled organizations where cooperatives are autonomous, self-help organizations controlled by their members.(no content)Cooperatives are democratic organizations in which members actively participate in setting policies and making decisions, with equal voting rights (one member, one vote).

## Technology/System Context

In the context of decentralized systems, cooperation enables all entities involved to share their resources, information, and responsibilities, such that mutual benefits are obtained and sustained.(no content)Cooperation involves all aspects of coordination as well as a resource-sharing dimension to support goal achievement, and commonly exhibits a division of labor component among all participants.

## Automotive/Vehicle Control

The Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control (CACC) is an extension to adaptive cruise control using Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) communication that realizes longitudinal automated vehicle control.

## Surveillance Systems

In surveillance, cooperative systems involve ground systems (such as SSR) that communicate with equipment on board aircraft to determine position and other details.

The term "cooperative control" is quite broad and can apply to various fields, from business organizations to technological systems.

Web search results for query: "Control system"

Links: [{"title":"Source Code Control System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Source_Code_Control_System"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Revision Control System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Revision_Control_System"},{"title":"Distributed control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_control_system"},{"title":"Global Command and Control System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Command_and_Control_System"},{"title":"Control system (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Industrial control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_control_system"},{"title":"Management control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Management_control_system"},{"title":"Systems control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_control"},{"title":"Mathematics of Control, Signals, and Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematics_of_Control,_Signals,_and_Systems"}]

## Control System

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about control systems:

### Definition
A control system manages, commands, directs, or regulates the behavior of other devices or systems using control loops.(no content)It can range from a single home heating controller using a thermostat controlling a domestic boiler to large industrial control systems.

### Types of Control Systems

**Closed-Loop vs. Open-Loop:**
A closed-loop controller or feedback controller is a control loop which incorporates feedback, in contrast to an open-loop controller or non-feedback controller, and uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.(no content)An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; the PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

**Industrial Control Systems:**
An industrial control system (ICS) is an electronic control system and associated instrumentation used for industrial process control.(no content)Larger systems are usually implemented by supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) systems, or DCSs, and programmable logic controllers (PLCs).

**Distributed Control Systems:**
Distributed control systems (DCS) are dedicated systems used in manufacturing processes that are continuous or batch-oriented.(no content)The key attribute of a DCS is its reliability due to the distribution of the control processing around nodes in the system, which mitigates a single processor failure.

### Operation
Control systems receive data from remote sensors measuring process variables, compare the collected data with desired setpoints, and derive command functions that are used to control a process through the final control elements, such as control valves.

Web search results for query: "Underwater acoustic communication"

Links: [{"title":"Underwater acoustic communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Underwater_acoustic_communication"},{"title":"Underwater acoustics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Underwater_acoustics"},{"title":"Acoustic communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acoustic_communication"},{"title":"Christine Erbe - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christine_Erbe"},{"title":"Milica Stojanovic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milica_Stojanovic"},{"title":"Pioneers of Underwater Acoustics Medal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pioneers_of_Underwater_Acoustics_Medal"}]

Here's comprehensive information about underwater acoustic communication:

## Overview

Underwater acoustic communication is a technique of sending and receiving messages in water.(no content)The most common method employs hydrophones.

## Challenges

Underwater communication is difficult due to factors such as multi-path propagation, time variations of the channel, small available bandwidth and strong signal attenuation, especially over long ranges.(no content)Compared to terrestrial communication, underwater communication has low data rates because it uses acoustic waves instead of electromagnetic waves.

## Key Applications

The need for underwater acoustic telemetry exists in applications such as data harvesting for environmental monitoring, communication with and between crewed and uncrewed underwater vehicles, and transmission of diver speech.

## Modulation Methods

Several modulation techniques are used for underwater acoustic communication:

- FSK is the earliest form of modulation used for acoustic modems, usually employing two distinct frequencies to modulate data; for example, frequency F1 to indicate bit 0 and frequency F2 to indicate bit 1.

- OFDM is a favorable communication scheme in underwater acoustic communications thanks to its resilience against frequency selective channels with long delay spreads.

## Historical Development

In April 2017, NATO's Centre for Maritime Research and Experimentation announced the approval of JANUS, a standardized protocol to transmit digital information underwater using acoustic sound, which uses 900 Hz to 60 kHz frequencies at distances of up to 28 kilometres.

Links: [{"title":"Hydrographic survey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrographic_survey"},{"title":"Type 636 hydrographic survey ship - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type_636_hydrographic_survey_ship"},{"title":"Snellius-class hydrographic survey vessel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snellius-class_hydrographic_survey_vessel"},{"title":"Type 635 hydrographic survey ship - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type_635_hydrographic_survey_ship"},{"title":"Category:McArthur-class hydrographic survey ships - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:McArthur-class_hydrographic_survey_ships"},{"title":"Canadian Hydrographic Service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_Hydrographic_Service"},{"title":"Hydrography - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrography"},{"title":"Italian ship UIOM - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_ship_UIOM"},{"title":"Buyskes-class hydrographic survey vessel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buyskes-class_hydrographic_survey_vessel"},{"title":"INS Ikshak - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/INS_Ikshak"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about hydrographic surveys:

## Definition and Purpose

Hydrographic survey is the science of measurement and description of features which affect maritime navigation, marine construction, dredging, offshore wind farms, offshore oil exploration and drilling and related activities.

## Scope of Surveys

Strong emphasis is placed on soundings, shorelines, tides, currents, seabed and submerged obstructions that relate to the previously mentioned activities. Additionally, surveys may be conducted to determine the route of subsea cables such as telecommunications cables, cables associated with wind farms, and HVDC power cables.

## Historical Methods

For many centuries, a hydrographic survey required the use of lead lines – ropes or lines with depth markings attached to lead weights to make one end sink to the bottom when lowered over the side of a ship or boat – and sounding poles, which were poles with depth markings which could be thrust over the side until they touched bottom, with depths measured manually and recorded, as did the position of each measurement with regard to mapped reference points as determined by three-point sextant fixes.

## Modern Technology

Surveys are increasingly conducted with the aid of aircraft and sophisticated equipment. Organizations like the Canadian Hydrographic Service have adopted advanced technologies including multi-beam echo-sounder sonar systems coupled with GPS to achieve improved survey accuracies.

## Organizational Structure

Hydrographic offices evolved from naval heritage and are usually found within national naval structures, with coordination of those organizations and product standardization conducted by the International Hydrographic Organization (IHO).

Web search results for query: "Autonomous underwater vehicle"

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous underwater vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_underwater_vehicle"},{"title":"Vityaz-D Autonomous Underwater Vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vityaz-D_Autonomous_Underwater_Vehicle"},{"title":"Unmanned underwater vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_underwater_vehicle"},{"title":"AUV-150 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AUV-150"},{"title":"Category:Autonomous underwater vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Autonomous_underwater_vehicles"},{"title":"Sentry (AUV) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sentry_(AUV)"},{"title":"REMUS (vehicle) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/REMUS_(vehicle)"},{"title":"Theseus (AUV) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theseus_(AUV)"},{"title":"Maya AUV India - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maya_AUV_India"},{"title":"Explorer AUV - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explorer_AUV"}]

Here are the search results for "Autonomous underwater vehicle":

## Overview

An autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) is a robot that travels underwater without requiring continuous input from an operator.(no content)AUVs constitute part of a larger group of undersea systems known as unmanned underwater vehicles, a classification that includes non-autonomous remotely operated underwater vehicles (ROVs) – controlled and powered from the surface by an operator/pilot via an umbilical or using remote control.

## History

The first AUV was developed at the Applied Physics Laboratory at the University of Washington as early as 1957 by Stan Murphy, Bob Francois and later on, Terry Ewart. The "Self-Propelled Underwater Research Vehicle", or SPURV, was used to study diffusion, acoustic transmission, and submarine wakes.

## Capabilities and Features

AUVs carry sensors to navigate autonomously and map features of the ocean. Typical sensors include compasses, depth sensors, sidescan and other sonars, magnetometers, thermistors and conductivity probes.(no content)Radio waves cannot penetrate water very far, so as soon as an AUV dives it loses its GPS signal. Therefore, a standard way for AUVs to navigate underwater is through dead reckoning.

## Power Systems

Most AUVs in use today are powered by rechargeable batteries (lithium ion, lithium polymer, nickel metal hydride etc.), and are implemented with some form of battery management system.

## Applications

Autonomous underwater vehicles, for example AUV ABYSS, have been used to find wreckage of missing airplanes, e.g. Air France Flight 447, and the Bluefin-21 AUV was used in the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

The "Self-Propelled Underwater Research Vehicle", or SPURV, was used to study diffusion, acoustic transmission, and submarine wakes.

## Capabilities and Features

AUVs carry sensors to navigate autonomously and map features of the ocean. Typical sensors include compasses, depth sensors, sidescan and other sonars, magnetometers, thermistors and conductivity probes.(no content)Radio waves cannot penetrate water very far, so as soon as an AUV dives it loses its GPS signal. Therefore, a standard way for AUVs to navigate underwater is through dead reckoning.

## Power Systems

Most AUVs in use today are powered by rechargeable batteries (lithium ion, lithium polymer, nickel metal hydride etc.), and are implemented with some form of battery management system.

## Applications

Autonomous underwater vehicles, for example AUV ABYSS, have been used to find wreckage of missing airplanes, e.g. Air France Flight 447, and the Bluefin-21 AUV was used in the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the AUV formation survey paper. Here's a summary:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** SURVEY

**Key Findings:**
- The paper is clearly a survey as it "presents a comprehensive survey of the state of the art of AUV formation research and development"
- It proposes a classification framework for organizing existing research but builds on and reviews existing work

**Extracted Triples (6 total):**

1. **Autonomous underwater vehicle** (artifact) - The primary technology subject of the survey
2. **Control theory** (concept) - Theoretical foundation for formation control methods
3. **Underwater acoustic communication** (method) - Essential for coordinating AUV formations
4. **Control system** (concept) - Applied in formation control systems
5. **Multi-agent system** (concept) - Conceptual framework for multiple coordinated AUVs
6. **Hydrographic survey** (task) - Key application domain for multi-AUV formations

**Validation Status:** ✅ All checks passed
- Paper type correctly classified as "survey"
- All 6 triples include valid Wikipedia URLs
- Entity type distribution: 1 artifact, 3 concepts, 1 method, 1 task
- All validation requirements met (at least 1 "uses" relation per paper)

Sources:

- [Multi-agent system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system)
